para.sentence: Define u_{k}=(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{k}}=(a-1)(a-2)\cdots(a-k), \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a-1}e^{-z}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{u_{k}}{z^{k}}+ R_{n}(a,z)\right), if n=1,2,\dots.
Then as z\to\infty with a and n fixed R_{n}(a,z)=O\left(z^{-n}\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{3}{2}\pi-\delta, where \delta denotes an arbitrary small positive constant.
If a is real and z ( =x ) is positive, then R_{n}(a,x) is bounded in absolute value by the first neglected term u_{n}/x^{n} and has the same sign provided that n\geq a-1.
For bounds on R_{n}(a,z) when a is real and z is complex see Olver (1997b, pp. 109–112).
For an exponentially-improved asymptotic expansion (§2.11(iii)) seeOlver (1991a).
\gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{k}}{{\left(a \right)_{k+1}}}, if a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.

This expansion is absolutely convergent for all finite z , and it can also be regarded as a generalized asymptotic expansion (§2.1(v)) of \gamma\left(a,z\right) as a\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta.
Also, P\left(a,z\right)\sim\frac{z^{a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(1+a\right)}\sim(2\pi a)^{- \frac{1}{2}}e^{a-z}(z/a)^{a}, if a\to\infty, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta.

If z=\lambda a , with \lambda fixed, then as a\to\infty \gamma\left(a,z\right)\sim-z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-a)^{k}b_{k}( \lambda)}{(z-a)^{2k+1}}, if 0<\lambda<1, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\frac{\pi}{2}-\delta.
\Gamma\left(a,z\right)\sim z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-a)^{k}b_{k}( \lambda)}{(z-a)^{2k+1}}, if \lambda>1, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\frac{3\pi}{2}-\delta.
where b_{0}(\lambda)=1,b_{1}(\lambda)=\lambda,b_{2}(\lambda)=\lambda(2\lambda+1), and for k=1,2,\dots , b_{k}(\lambda)=\lambda(1-\lambda)b_{k-1}^{\prime}(\lambda)+(2k-1)\lambda b_{k- 1}(\lambda).
Sharp error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension for (8.11.7) can be found in Nemes (2016).
This reference also contains explicit formulas for b_{k}(\lambda) in terms of Stirling numbers and for the case \lambda>1 an asymptotic expansion for b_{k}(\lambda) as k\to\infty.

The expansion (8.11.7) also applies when a is replaced by -a , \lambda<0 and |{\rm ph}\,a|\leq\frac{3\pi}{2}-\omega-\delta with \omega={\rm ph}(-\lambda+\ln\left(-\lambda\right)+\pi i) , 0<\omega<\pi.
For error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension for this later expansion, see Nemes (2015c).
If x=a+(2a)^{\frac{1}{2}}y and a\to+\infty , then P\left(a+1,x\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(-y\right)-\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi a}}(1+y^{2})e^{-y^{2}}+O\left(a^{-1}\right),
in both cases uniformly with respect to bounded real values of y.
For Dawson’s integral F\left(y\right) see §7.2(ii).
SeeTricomi (1950b) for these approximations, together with higher terms and extensions to complex variables.
For related expansions involving Hermite polynomials see Pagurova (1965).

As z\to\infty , \Gamma\left(z,z\right)\sim z^{z-1}e^{-z}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}z^{\frac{1}{ 2}}-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{2\pi}}{24z^{\frac{1}{2}}}-\frac{4}{135z}+\frac{ \sqrt{2\pi}}{576z^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{8}{2835z^{2}}+\dots\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq 2\pi-\delta.
For sharp error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension, see Nemes (2016).
This reference also contains explicit formulas for the coefficients in terms of Stirling numbers.
For the function e_{n}(z) defined by (8.4.11),

\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{e_{n}(nx)}{e^{nx}}=\begin{cases}0,&x>1,\\ \tfrac{1}{2},&x=1,\\ 1,&0\leq x<1.\end{cases } With x=1 , an asymptotic expansion of e_{n}(nx)/e^{nx} follows from (8.11.14) and (8.11.16).
If S_{n}(x) is defined by e^{nx}=e_{n}(nx)+\frac{(nx)^{n}}{n!}S_{n}(x) , then S_{n}(x)=\frac{\gamma\left(n+1,nx\right)}{(nx)^{n}e^{-nx}}.

Also, S_{n}(x)\sim\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}d_{k}(x)n^{-k}, if n\to\infty, uniformly for x\in(-\infty,1-\delta] , with d_{k}(x)=\frac{(-1)^{k}b_{k}(x)}{(1-x)^{2k+1}}, if k=0,1,2,\dots, and b_{k}(x) as in §8.11(iii).
For (8.11.18) and extensions to complex values of x seeBuckholtz (1963).
For a uniformly valid expansion for n\to\infty and x\in[\delta,1] , see Wong (1973b).
